thread.title: Planned Parenthood to reject pay for fetal tissue
thread.title_full: Planned Parenthood to reject pay for fetal tissue

author: Ian K. Kullgren | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Planned Parenthood to reject pay for fetal tissue
text:
Comments 
SALEM — Portland's Planned Parenthood chapter said Tuesday that it will stop taking reimbursements for scientific research on fetal tissue, following an order handed down by the group's national leaders. 
In a powerfully worded statement, the president and CEO of Planned Parenthood Columbia Willamette, Stacy Cross, said the change would disarm Republican accusations that Planned Parenthood profits from the sale of fetal tissue from abortions. 
"This new policy removes beyond the shadow of a doubt the ludicrous idea that Planned Parenthood has any financial interest in fetal tissue donation — and shows the real agenda behind these attacks: Banning abortion in the United States," Cross said in the statement. 
Planned Parenthood's announcement came in response to political backlash from Republicans — in the Oregon Legislature and in Congress — over edited videos that claim to show the group profiting from fetal tissue sales. Planned Parenthood's national president, Cecil Richards, notified the National Institutes of Health on Tuesday that the group would stop accepting payments, even though she said in a letter that the current policy "exceeds the legal requirements," the Associated Press reported. 
Oregon Rep. Bill Post , R-Keizer, said the announcement doesn't erase questions over whether Planned Parenthood and Oregon Health & Science University broke state or federal law. 
"I think we still don't know the answer to that question," Post said. 
Oregon is one of only a few states that permits the transfer of fetal tissue for scientific research. In a recent letter to House Republicans, Oregon Health & Science University said it gave Planned Parenthood Columbia Willamette $19,000 to cover facilities and personnel costs for two studies involving donated placental tissue. The university has said the studies are related to still births and pregnancy complications. 
Cross, in the statement, said the new policy will apply to future research contracts. The current contract will expire in September 2016. 
In the letter, Oregon Health & Science University said it did pay Advance Bioscience Laboratories, a Maryland-based research group, for 123 fetal parts that run $230-$340 apiece. Post said that information is bound to inspire more questions from Republicans, although they haven't decided how to proceed. 
— Ian K. Kullgren
